trans-unit.source: How to Check Job Progress using .NET
trans-unit.target: How to Check Job Progress using .NET

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use event handler code to track job progress and send status updates. Code samples are written in C# and use the Media Services SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use event handler code to track job progress and send status updates. Code samples are written in C# and use the Media Services SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: When you run jobs, you often require a way to track job progress.
trans-unit.target: When you run jobs, you often require a way to track job progress.

trans-unit.source: You can check the progress by [defining a StateChanged event handler](#statechangeeventhandler) or [using Azure Queue storage to monitor Media Services job notifications](#checkprogresswith_queues).
trans-unit.target: You can check the progress by [defining a StateChanged event handler](#statechangeeventhandler) or [using Azure Queue storage to monitor Media Services job notifications](#checkprogresswith_queues).

trans-unit.source: Both methods are described in this topic.
trans-unit.target: Both methods are described in this topic.

trans-unit.source: The following code example defines the StateChanged event handler.
trans-unit.target: The following code example defines the StateChanged event handler.

trans-unit.source: This event handler tracks job progress and provides updated status, depending on the state.
trans-unit.target: This event handler tracks job progress and provides updated status, depending on the state.

trans-unit.source: The code also defines the LogJobStop method.
trans-unit.target: The code also defines the LogJobStop method.

trans-unit.source: This helper method logs error details.
trans-unit.target: This helper method logs error details.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure Media Services has the ability to deliver notification messages to the <linkText>Azure Queue storage</linkText><title></title> when processing media jobs.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure Media Services has the ability to deliver notification messages to the <linkText>Azure Queue storage</linkText><title></title> when processing media jobs.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows how to get these notification messages from Queue storage.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows how to get these notification messages from Queue storage.

trans-unit.source: Messages delivered to Queue storage can be accessed from anywhere in the world.
trans-unit.target: Messages delivered to Queue storage can be accessed from anywhere in the world.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Queue messaging architecture is reliable and highly scalable.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Queue messaging architecture is reliable and highly scalable.

trans-unit.source: Polling Queue storage is recommended over using other methods.
trans-unit.target: Polling Queue storage is recommended over using other methods.

trans-unit.source: One common scenario for listening to Media Services notifications is if you are developing a content management system that needs to perform some additional task after an encoding job completes (for example, trigger the next step in a workflow, or publish content).
trans-unit.target: One common scenario for listening to Media Services notifications is if you are developing a content management system that needs to perform some additional task after an encoding job completes (for example, trigger the next step in a workflow, or publish content).

trans-unit.source: Consider the following when developing Media Services applications that use Azure storage queue.
trans-unit.target: Consider the following when developing Media Services applications that use Azure storage queue.

trans-unit.source: The Queues service does not provide a guarantee of first-in-first-out (FIFO) ordered delivery.
trans-unit.target: The Queues service does not provide a guarantee of first-in-first-out (FIFO) ordered delivery.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues Compared and Contrasted</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues Compared and Contrasted</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Queues is not a push service; you have to poll the queue.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Queues is not a push service; you have to poll the queue.

trans-unit.source: You can have any number of queues.
trans-unit.target: You can have any number of queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Queue Service REST API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Queue Service REST API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Queues has some limitations and specifics that are described in the following article: <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues Compared and Contrasted</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Queues has some limitations and specifics that are described in the following article: <linkText>Azure Queues and Azure Service Bus Queues Compared and Contrasted</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The code example in this section does the following:
trans-unit.target: The code example in this section does the following:

trans-unit.source: Defines the EncodingJobMessage class that maps to the notification message format.
trans-unit.target: Defines the EncodingJobMessage class that maps to the notification message format.

trans-unit.source: The code deserializes messages received from the queue into objects of the EncodingJobMessage type.
trans-unit.target: The code deserializes messages received from the queue into objects of the EncodingJobMessage type.

trans-unit.source: Loads the Media Services and Storage account information from the app.config file.
trans-unit.target: Loads the Media Services and Storage account information from the app.config file.

trans-unit.source: Uses this information to create the CloudMediaContext and CloudQueue objects.
trans-unit.target: Uses this information to create the CloudMediaContext and CloudQueue objects.

trans-unit.source: Creates the queue that will be receiving notification messages about the encoding job.
trans-unit.target: Creates the queue that will be receiving notification messages about the encoding job.

trans-unit.source: Creates the notification end point that is mapped to the queue.
trans-unit.target: Creates the notification end point that is mapped to the queue.

trans-unit.source: Attaches the notification end point to the job and submits the encoding job.
trans-unit.target: Attaches the notification end point to the job and submits the encoding job.

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple notification end points attached to a job.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple notification end points attached to a job.

trans-unit.source: In this example we are only interested in final states of the job processing, so we pass NotificationJobState.FinalStatesOnly to the AddNew method.
trans-unit.target: In this example we are only interested in final states of the job processing, so we pass NotificationJobState.FinalStatesOnly to the AddNew method.

trans-unit.source: If you pass NotificationJobState.All you should expect to get all state change notifications: Queued -> Scheduled -> Processing -> Finished.
trans-unit.target: If you pass NotificationJobState.All you should expect to get all state change notifications: Queued -> Scheduled -> Processing -> Finished.

trans-unit.source: However, as noted earlier, the Azure Storage Queues service does not guarantee ordered delivery.
trans-unit.target: However, as noted earlier, the Azure Storage Queues service does not guarantee ordered delivery.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Timestamp property (defined on the EncodingJobMessage type in the example below) to order messages.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Timestamp property (defined on the EncodingJobMessage type in the example below) to order messages.

trans-unit.source: It is possible that you will get duplicate notification messages.
trans-unit.target: It is possible that you will get duplicate notification messages.

trans-unit.source: Use the ETag property (defined on the EncodingJobMessage type) to check for duplicates.
trans-unit.target: Use the ETag property (defined on the EncodingJobMessage type) to check for duplicates.

trans-unit.source: Note that it is also possible that some state change notifications will be skipped.
trans-unit.target: Note that it is also possible that some state change notifications will be skipped.

trans-unit.source: Waits for the job to get to the Finished state by checking the queue every 10 seconds.
trans-unit.target: Waits for the job to get to the Finished state by checking the queue every 10 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Deletes messages after they have been processed.
trans-unit.target: Deletes messages after they have been processed.

trans-unit.source: Deletes the queue and the notification end point.
trans-unit.target: Deletes the queue and the notification end point.

trans-unit.source: The recommended way to monitor a job’s state is by listening to notification messages, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: The recommended way to monitor a job’s state is by listening to notification messages, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you could check on a job’s state by using the IJob.State property.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you could check on a job’s state by using the IJob.State property.

trans-unit.source: Note that a notification message about a job’s completion may arrive before the State on IJob is set to Finished.
trans-unit.target: Note that a notification message about a job’s completion may arrive before the State on IJob is set to Finished.

trans-unit.source: The IJob.State property will reflect the accurate state with a slight delay.
trans-unit.target: The IJob.State property will reflect the accurate state with a slight delay.

trans-unit.source: The example above produced the following output.
trans-unit.target: The example above produced the following output.

trans-unit.source: You values will vary.
trans-unit.target: You values will vary.
